title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: In November 2018, Greene posted on Facebook that the deadly [[Camp Fire (2018)|Camp Fire]] in California was the result of a "space laser so California could built a high speed rail system" with the involvement of [[Rothschild & Co|Rothchild Inc.,]] a mainstay of anti-Semitic conspiracy theorists."<ref>{{Cite web|title=QAnon Congresswoman Also Believes a Space Laser Sparked the Camp Fire|url=https://earther.gizmodo.com/qanon-congresswoman-also-believes-a-space-laser-sparked-1846152493|access-date=2021-01-28|website=Earther|language=en-us}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: [[WRCB]]-TV reporter Meredith Aldis was threatened with arrest on January 27, 2021, when she tried to ask a question at a town hall event about a [https://www.axios.com/david-hogg-marjorie-taylor-green-harassment-8fbfb81a-3745-40d3-973b-b5daca948d86.html 2019 video] in which Taylor Greene is seen harassing teenage survivor of the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]] and gun control advocate, David Hogg.<ref>{{cite news |last1=O'KANE |first1=CAITLIN |title=Reporter says she was threatened with arrest after trying to ask Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene a question at town hall |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/marjorie-taylor-greene-town-hall-reporter-question/?ftag=CNM-00-10aab6a&linkId=110170629&fbclid=IwAR0cXIN33_AtKNoLsJYIM6E2s-0Gtec0TLDGPRVZkSPWNPXc45Hqx0XpxkU |access-date=January 28, 2021 |work=cbsnews.com |publisher=CBS News |date=January 28, 2021}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: === Ruth Bader Ginsburg conspiracy theory ===

In February 2019, Greene supported the claim that Supreme Court Justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] used a body double in a public appearance.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hananoki|first=Eric|title=Marjorie Taylor Greene in 2019 suggested Ruth Bader Ginsburg was replaced with a body double|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/supreme-court/marjorie-taylor-greene-2019-suggested-ruth-bader-ginsburg-was-replaced-body-double|access-date=2021-01-29|website=Media Matters for America|language=en}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: === Ties to extremist militia groups ===

On January 29, 2021, the ''New York Times'' detailed Greene’s support for and past ties with extremist militia groups, including the [[Three Percenters]] and the [[Oath Keepers]], some of whose members participated in the [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|last=Broadwater|first=Luke|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Matthew|date=2021-01-29|title=Republican Ties to Extremist Groups Are Under Scrutiny|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/29/us/republicans-trump-capitol-riot.html|access-date=2021-01-29|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>  In the same article, the ''New York Times'' published a photo noting that members of the Three Percenters provided security for Greene at a 2020 campaign event in [[Ringgold, Georgia|Ringgold]], Georgia.<ref name=":1" />

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: === Call for violence ===

In an interview with gun activist Chris Dorr prior to election day, Greene told viewers "The only way you get your freedoms back is it’s earned with the price of blood."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Follman|first=Mark|title=A newly uncovered video shows Majorie Taylor Greene endorsed political violence just before Election Day|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2021/01/marjorie-taylor-greene-endorsed-political-violence-video-guns-elections-congress/|access-date=2021-01-29|website=Mother Jones|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: In a January 2021 report, ''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]'' published an article summarizing "Every Disturbing Conspiracy Marjorie Taylor Greene Believes In."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gilbert |first1=David |title=Here's Every Disturbing Conspiracy Marjorie Taylor Greene Believes In: A complete conspiracy compendium |url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/3an47j/heres-every-disturbing-conspiracy-marjorie-taylor-greene-believes-in |website=Vice.com |publisher=Vice |access-date=30 January 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130060821/https://www.vice.com/en/article/3an47j/heres-every-disturbing-conspiracy-marjorie-taylor-greene-believes-in |archive-date=30 January 2021 |date=29 January 2021 |quote=Georgia Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene does not discriminate — at least when it comes to conspiracy theories. |url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
deleted: Her father sold the company to Greene and her husband, Perry, in 2002.<ref name="NWYR20201009" />
The couple are respectively vice president and president of the company.<ref name="SPLC2019" />

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: Fred Guttenberg however did not consider Greene's postings to be a joking matter in a comment to the ''Los Angeles Times'', saying "She denies that my daughter died in Parkland … and yet, because my last name is Guttenberg, because I am Jewish, she thinks I shoot lasers at forests and start fires."<ref name="LAT20210130">{{cite news|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|title=Truth set ablaze by conspiracy theories|author1-first=Hailey|author1-last=Branson Potts|author2-first=Joseph|author2-last=Serna|author3-first=Alejandra|author3-last=Reyes-Velarde|date=2021-01-30}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: Prior to February 4, 2021:

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: Greene was a top official of the Family America Project, a conservative group founded in January 2018. She was a moderator of the organization's Facebook group which included death threats against Democrats, bigotry directed at the Obamas and support for various conspiracy theories, including for the [[John Birch Society]] that claimed during the 1950s that the United States government had been infiltrated by communists.<ref>https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2021/02/marjorie-taylor-greene-facebook-john-birch-society/</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: Greene was a top official of the Family America Project, a conservative group founded in January 2018. She was a moderator of the organization's Facebook group which included death threats against Democrats, bigotry directed at the Obamas and support for various conspiracy theories, including for the [[John Birch Society]] that claimed during the 1950s that the United States government had been infiltrated by communists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2021/02/marjorie-taylor-greene-facebook-john-birch-society/|title=Marjorie Taylor Greene was a moderator of a Facebook group featuring death threats and racist memes.|first=David|last=Corn}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: Greene has made multiple controversial and incendiary statements both before and during office in support of conspiracy theories. She has also been reported to have ties to militia groups and calling for the execution toward Democratic politicians and FBI agents as part of the "deep state" against Trump.<ref>{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=Em Steck and Andrew Kaczynski|title=Marjorie Taylor Greene indicated support for executing prominent Democrats in 2018 and 2019 before running for Congress|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/politics/marjorie-taylor-greene-democrats-violence/index.html|access-date=2021-02-05|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
added: In late January, 2021, Greene accepted an interview with far right U.K. political commentator [[Katie Hopkins]] in which Greene mentioned that "she'd love to trade (Hopkins) for some of our white people here that have no appreciation for our country."<ref>{{cite news |last= Peat|first= Jack|date= January 28, 2021|title= US Congresswoman tells Katie Hopkins: “We’d love to trade you for some of our own white people”|work= The London Economic|location= London|Access-date= February 20, 2021}}</ref>
